abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Sustainable Forestry for
            Rural Development Project for Lao People's Democratic
            Republic were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory; risk to development outcome was substantial;
            bank performance was moderately satisfactory; and borrower
            performance also moderately satisfactory. Some of the
            lessons learned included: institutional arrangement, one of
            the key challenges in the original phase of the project was
            the institutional arrangements did little to clarify the
            roles and responsibilities of the organizations involved.
            Capacity assessment, while significant investments and
            improvements have been made in strengthening capacity of the
            implementing agency, the importance of accurately assessing
            capacity during appraisal cannot be overstated. Community
            development challenges, the complexity of social dynamics
            and community development was also underestimated, and the
            diversity of ethnic groups, resource practices, and
            languages compounded these challenges. Finance and
            procurement arrangement, although the implementing agency
            had prior experience of bank financing and procurement
            compliance requirements establishing the required
            arrangements took longer than anticipated. Inclusive
            principles and Practice, the project adopted an inclusive
            approach and prioritized ethnic group communities, but
            translating these principles into practice remained a
            challenge. Independent Participatory Sustainable Forest
            Management (PSFM) Monitoring, The project introduced the
            concept of rapid surveys conducted by professionals both
            outside and inside line organizations to focus on selected activities.
